intro: Quercus stellata var. rufescens, commonly known as the redleaf chinquapin, is a variant of the chinquapin oak native to the southeastern United States. It is a deciduous shrub or small tree characterized by its oval to elliptical leaves that turn reddish-brown in the fall. The plant produces small, clustered acorns that are an important food source for wildlife. Its leaves are typically 2–5 inches long and have a smooth or slightly hairy upper surface. The species is often found in moist, well-drained soils in woodland habitats.
